docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare is such a hot political potato that politicians here realized long ago that using normal legislative procedures, they would never be able to agree on measures to make the program financially secure for baby boomers when they retire. So they took a traditional Washington escape route. They voted last summer to create a commission to tell them what hard choices to make.

headline.main: Partisanship Imperils Advisory Panel on Medicare

docs.abstract: David E Rosenbaum analysis says commission created to recommend ways for making Medicare financially secure faces an all but insurmountable task both because of partisanship that infects most things in Washington and because of the natural unwillingness to take political risks (M)
docs.snippet: Medicare is such a hot political potato that politicians here realized long ago that using normal legislative procedures, they would never be able to agree on measures to make the program financially secure for baby boomers when they retire.    So...

Gephardt, the House minority leader; Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, and Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader. One more member, the chairman, is still to be appointed jointly by Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Lott. Here are the 16 members named so far and the official who appointed them:

docs.lead_paragraph: Less than six months after announcing that it hoped to expand Medicaid to cover all low-income people who are infected with the AIDS virus, the Clinton Administration has backed away from the plan, saying it cannot be done nationwide without increasing spending. ''We have not been able to find a revenue-neutral way to do it,'' Victor Zonana, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services, said today. Instead, the Administration was hoping states would submit proposals to make the change on their own. Maine, Massachusetts and Florida have already expressed an interest, Mr. Zonana said.

headline.main: White House Drops Plan for Medicaid to Cover Cost of AIDS Drugs for Poor

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration backs away from plan to expand Medicaid to cover all low-income people who are infected with AIDS virus; says it cannot be done without increasing spending; Vice Pres Al Gore, who promoted idea, remains 'strongly committed to expanding medical coverage for people living with AIDS' (M)
docs.snippet: Less than six months after announcing that it hoped to expand Medicaid to cover all low-income people who are infected with the AIDS virus, the Clinton Administration has backed away from the plan, saying it cannot be done nationwide without...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof writes a very amusing and disturbing article about an episode of malaria he developed after returning to Japan (Week in Review, Nov. 30). His point seems to be that his care was in many ways better -- and a lot cheaper -- than what he would have received in the United States. I believe he is mistaken. Mr. Kristof's illness was correctly diagnosed and treated only after his office was able to locate a leading specialist in Tokyo who had the correct medication available. Leaving aside the question of insurance and access to care, if Mr. Kristof had arrived by ambulance at any hospital in the United States with a temperature of 104 degrees, a history of a recent trip to Africa and a stated belief that he had malaria, his care would have been very different from what it was in Japan. His blood would have been tested for malaria and appropriate therapy begun soon afterward. His bill would have been much higher, but he would not have needed to find an expert in malaria.
docs.abstract: John Meyerhoff letter says Nicholas D Krisof's Nov 30 article on being treated for malaria in Japan seemed to imply, quite wrongly, that his care was in many ways better than what he would have received in US (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Nicholas D. Kristof writes a very amusing and disturbing article about an episode of malaria he developed after returning to Japan (Week in Review, Nov. 30). His point seems to be that his care was in many ways better -- and a lot...

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City residents on Medicaid and in private pay plans have a difficult time navigating the managed health care system and, as a result, they often do not get appropriate medical care, according to two reports released yesterday. Whether people are looking for information to help them decide which plan to join or trying to resolve a dispute over whether a particular treatment is covered, the two studies concluded that the companies often withhold facts they are legally required to provide, or give misleading and erroneous information.

headline.main: 2 Studies Say H.M.O. Plans Provide Poor Information

docs.abstract: Two studies find that New York City residents on Medicaid and in private insurance plans have difficult time navigating managed health care system and, as a result, often do not get appropriate treatment; Public Advocate's Office and consumer coalition find that patients are paying greater out-of-pocket expenses for drugs they erroneously think are covered by their plans, and are failing to seek specialty care because they cannot figure out if it is covered; Mark Green, Public Advocate, notes problems persist despite state's new Managed Care Bill of Rights; coalition recommends centralized ombudsman to provide independent information (M)
docs.snippet: New York City residents on Medicaid and in private pay plans have a difficult time navigating the managed health care system and, as a result, they often do not get appropriate medical care, according to two reports released yesterday.    Whether...

docs.lead_paragraph: In his first extensive interview about the fund-raising storm that has enveloped him for nearly a year, a defiant Vice President Al Gore today refused to concede that he had made any mistakes in how he raised money or how he handled the political accusations against him. Casting the furor in partisan terms, Mr. Gore asserted that ''the Republican Party is bound and determined to prevent change'' in campaign financing.

headline.main: Gore Refuses to Concede Fund-Raising Mistakes

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore, in interview with New York Times, refuses to concede that he had made any mistakes in how he raised money or how he handled political accusations against him; says Republican Party is determined to prevent change in campaign financing; says it is unfair for people to dwell on months of publicity about his appearance at Buddhist temple, fund-raising solicitations from White House and his legalistic defense of himself at news conference in March (M)
docs.snippet: In his first extensive interview about the fund-raising storm that has enveloped him for nearly a year, a defiant Vice President Al Gore today refused to concede that he had made any mistakes in how he raised money or how he handled the political...

docs.lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Harley Everett envisioned a burgeoning industry that would rid meats, fruits and vegetables of harmful bacteria by bathing them briefly in gamma rays. His company built an irradiation plant, tucked away on a dusty road in the phosphate mining town of Mulberry, Fla. But business is hardly thriving. His company's plant remains the only one in the nation built solely to irradiate food. Down the hall from Mr. Everett's office on a recent day, behind six-foot-thick concrete walls, slender rods of radioactive cobalt glowing ice blue waited uselessly in a deep pool of water. The plant was silent, its parking lot all but empty. There was no food to irradiate.

headline.main: TECHNOLOGY IN WAITING: A special report.; Long Quest for Safer Food Revisits Radiation Method

docs.abstract: Special report Technology In Waiting focuses on public indifference to irradiation as way to rid food of harmful bacteria; process, newly approved for red meat and approved years ago for chicken, fruits and vegetables is little used despite relatively low cost; it remains to be seen whether recent outbreaks of food poisoning and recalls of meat contaminated with E coli bacteria will spur consumer demand for irradiated foods; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Five years ago, Harley Everett envisioned a burgeoning industry that would rid meats, fruits and vegetables of harmful bacteria by bathing them briefly in gamma rays. His company built an irradiation plant, tucked away on a dusty road in the...

byline.original: By GINA KOLATA with CHRISTOPHER DREW

docs.lead_paragraph: Gillian Al-mathil, a large woman with an indomitable gait, strode across Jeff Lettieri's territory at 40th Street and Second Avenue in Manhattan and rapped on the window of his red, white and blue truck. ''O.K., Snapple man, where are you?'' she asked. ''Just when you going to take care of me?'' Mr. Lettieri pointed to the Sloan's supermarket before them. ''First, them. Then we get to you. Got to keep you happy.''

headline.main: On the Front Lines Of the Beverage Wars; The Life of a Snapple Distributor: Surviving Robbers, Illegal Parkers And the Usual Cutthroat Competition

docs.abstract: Profile of Jeff Lettieri describes day in life a beverage distributor in Manhattan; Lettieri is an independent distributor for Snapple Beverage Corp and its 27 teas and juice drinks; he is salesman, truck loader, heavy lifter and bill collector, all in one; in fiercely competitive beverage industry, he is a foot soldier on front lines; people like Lettieri are crucial to future of Snapple, which first caught on in health food stores of Greenwich Village, became phenomenal national success story, then suffered disastrous setbacks after Quaker Oats bought company three years ago; now Snapple has returned to its New York roots, and Manhattan company that bought brand from Quaker in May has vowed to focus on Lettieri's kind of store-to-store, street-level salesmanship; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE patient has had a bad year: on that much the doctors all agree. But their opinions on the underlying diagnosis and prognosis differ radically. Some say the 150-year-old American Medical Association is still very much its old healthy self: the pre-eminent medical association in the country, almost 300,000-strong, devoted to safeguarding the profession's highest moral and ethical principles.

headline.main: After Bad Year for A.M.A., Doctors Debate Its Prognosis

docs.abstract: Many doctors are wondering more vocally than ever whether American Medical Association that claims to speak for them still has any real right to do so; organization's membership is declining; its policy-making body espouses views far to the right of any members, especially younger doctors, and its continuing efforts to protect turf of American-trained doctors gives support to critics who say it operates more like a trade union than a professional organization; only about 40 percent of country's roughly 700,000 doctors and 55 percent of its medical students are members, in contract with organization's heyday in 1960's, when about 90 percent of doctors in private practice belonged; graph (L)
docs.snippet: THE patient has had a bad year: on that much the doctors all agree. But their opinions on the underlying diagnosis and prognosis differ radically.    Some say the 150-year-old American Medical Association is still very much its old healthy self: the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional leaders named 10 people today to a new Federal advisory commission that will recommend ways of preserving Medicare for 76 million baby boomers, but President Clinton held up his selections because of wrangling with the Republican leaders over appointment of a chairman. In addition, Speaker Newt Gingrich required his appointments to accept a precondition: that they would not turn to tax increases to solve Medicare's long-term financial problems. One candidate declined to accept on those grounds.

headline.main: Political Wrangling Delays Selection of Medicare Panel

docs.abstract: Congressional leaders name 10 people to new Federal advisory commission that will recommend ways of preserving Medicare for 76 million baby boomers, but Pres Clinton holds up his selections because of wrangling with Republican leaders over appointment of chairman; seven members of commission remain unnamed as December 2 deadline approaches (M)
